summary.long: 1 Samuel is a book of the Old Testament.

verses.text: There was a man named Elkanah from Ramathaim Zophim in the mountains of Ephraim. He was the son of Jeroham, grandson of Elihu, great-grandson of Tohu, whose father was Zuph from the tribe of Ephraim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Elkanah had two wives, one named Hannah, the other Peninnah. Peninnah had children, but Hannah had none.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Every year this man would go from his own city to worship and sacrifice to Yahweh Tsebaoth at Shiloh. Eli’s two sons, Hophni and Phinehas, served there as priests of Yahweh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whenever Elkanah offered a sacrifice, he would give portions of it to his wife Peninnah and all her sons and daughters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He would also give one portion to Hannah because he loved her, even though Yahweh had kept her from having children.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Because Yahweh had made her unable to have children, her rival Peninnah tormented her endlessly in order to make her miserable.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This happened year after year. Whenever Hannah went to Yahweh’s house, Peninnah would make her miserable, and Hannah would cry and not eat.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Her husband Elkanah would ask her, “Hannah, why are you crying? Why haven’t you eaten? Why are you so downhearted? Don’t I mean more to you than ten sons?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One day, after Hannah had something to eat and drink in Shiloh, she got up. (The priest Eli was sitting on a chair by the door of Yahweh’s temple.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Though she was resentful, she prayed to Yahweh while she cried.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She made this vow, “Yahweh Tsebaoth, if you will look at my misery, remember me, and give me a boy, then I will give him to you for as long as he lives. A razor will never be used on his head.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While Hannah was praying a long time in front of Yahweh, Eli was watching her mouth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She was praying silently. Her voice couldn’t be heard; only her lips were moving. Eli thought she was drunk.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “How long are you going to stay drunk?” Eli asked her. “Get rid of your wine.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hannah responded, “No sir. I’m not drunk. I’m depressed. I’m pouring out my heart to Yahweh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Don’t take me to be a good-for-nothing woman. I was praying like this because I’ve been troubled and tormented.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Eli replied, “Go in peace, and may the Elohim of Israel grant your request.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “May you continue to be kind to me,” she said. Then the woman went her way and ate. She was no longer sad.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Early in the morning Elkanah and his family got up and worshiped in front of Yahweh. Then they returned home to Ramah. Elkanah made love to his wife Hannah, and Yahweh remembered her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hannah became pregnant and gave birth to a son. She named him Samuel [God Hears], because she said, “I asked Yahweh for him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: To keep his vow, Elkanah and his entire household again went to offer the annual sacrifice to Yahweh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Hannah didn’t go. She told her husband, “I’ll wait until the boy is weaned. Then I’ll bring him and present him to Yahweh, and he’ll stay there permanently.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Do what you think is best,” her husband Elkanah told her. “Wait until you’ve weaned him. May Yahweh keep his word.” The woman stayed and nursed her son until she had weaned him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As soon as she had weaned Samuel, she took him with her. She also brought a three-year-old bull, half a bushel of flour, and a full wineskin. She brought him to Yahweh’s house at Shiloh while the boy was still a child.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the parents butchered the bull and brought the child to Eli.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Sir,” Hannah said, “as sure as you live, I’m the woman who stood here next to you and prayed to Yahweh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I prayed for this child, and Yahweh granted my request.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
In return, I am giving him to Yahweh. He will be dedicated to Yahweh for his whole life.”
And they worshiped Yahweh there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Hannah prayed out loud,
“My heart finds joy in Yahweh.
My head is lifted to Yahweh.
My mouth mocks my enemies.
    I rejoice because you saved me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
There is no one holy like Yahweh.
There is no one but you, O Lord.
There is no Tsur like our Elohim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Do not boast
    or let arrogance come out of your mouth
        because Yahweh is an El of knowledge,
            and he weighs our actions.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“The bows of the warriors are broken,
    but those who stumble are armed with strength.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Those who were well-fed hire themselves out for a piece of bread,
    but those who were hungry hunger no more.
    Even the woman who was childless gives birth to seven children,
        but the mother of many children grieves all alone.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Yahweh kills, and he gives life.
He makes people go down to the grave, and he raises them up again.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yahweh causes poverty and grants wealth.
    He humbles people; he also promotes them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He raises the poor from the dust.
    He lifts the needy from the trash heap
        in order to make them sit with nobles
            and even to make them inherit a glorious throne.
“The pillars of the earth are Yahweh’s.
    He has set the world on them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He safeguards the steps of his faithful ones,
    but wicked people are silenced in darkness
        because humans cannot succeed by their own strength.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Those who oppose Yahweh are broken into pieces.
    He thunders at them from the heavens.
Yahweh judges the ends of the earth.
    He gives strength to his King
        and lifts the head of his Messiah.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Elkanah went home to Ramah. But the boy Samuel served Yahweh under the priest Eli.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Eli’s sons, Hophni and Phinehas, were good-for-nothing priests; they had no faith in Yahweh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, this was how the priests dealt with the people who were offering sacrifices: While the meat was boiling, the priest’s servant would come with a three-pronged fork in his hand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he would stick it into the pot, kettle, cauldron, or pan. Whatever the fork brought up from the pot belonged to the priest. This is what the priests did in Shiloh to all the people of Israel who came there to sacrifice.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But in the case of Eli’s sons, even before the people burned the fat, their servants would come and say to the man who was sacrificing, “Give the meat to the priest to roast. He doesn’t want boiled meat from you. He wants it raw.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If the man said to the servant, “First let the fat be burned, then take as much as you want,” the servant would say to him, “Give it to me now, or I’ll take it by force.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sin of Eli’s sons was a serious matter to Yahweh, because these men were treating the offerings made to Yahweh with contempt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Meanwhile, Samuel continued to serve in front of Yahweh. As a boy he was already wearing a linen ephod.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His mother would make him a robe and bring it to him every year when she went with her husband to offer the annual sacrifice.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Eli would bless Elkanah (and his wife) and say, “May Yahweh give you children from this woman in place of the one which she has given to Yahweh.” Then they would go home.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yahweh came to Hannah. She became pregnant five times and had three sons and two daughters. Meanwhile, the boy Samuel grew up in front of Yahweh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, Eli was very old, and he had heard everything that his sons were doing to all Israel and that they were sleeping with the women who served at the gate of the tent of meeting.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he asked them, “Why are you doing such things? I hear about your wicked ways from all these people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Sons, the report that I hear the people of Yahweh spreading isn’t good!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If one person sins against another, Elohim will take care of him. However, when a person sins against Yahweh, who will pray for him?” But they wouldn’t listen to their father’s warning—Yahweh wanted to kill them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The boy Samuel continued to grow and gained the favor of Yahweh and the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then a man of Elohim came to Eli and said to him, “This is what Yahweh says: I revealed myself to your ancestors when they were under Pharaoh’s control in Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I chose one of your ancestors out of all the tribes of Israel to serve as my priest, to sacrifice burnt offerings on my altar, to burn incense, and to wear the ephod in my presence. And I gave your ancestors the right to keep portions of the sacrifices that the people of Israel burned on the altar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Why do you show no respect for my sacrifices and grain offerings that I have commanded people to make in my dwelling place? Why do you honor your sons more than me by making yourselves fat on the best of all the sacrifices offered by my people Israel?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Therefore, Yahweh Elohim of Israel declares: I certainly thought that your family and your father’s family would always live in my presence.
“But now Yahweh declares: I promise that I will honor those who honor me, and those who despise me will be considered insignificant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The time is coming when I will break your strength and the strength of your father’s house so that no one will grow old in your family.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You will see distress in my dwelling place. In spite of the good that I do for Israel, no one in your family will live to an old age.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Any man in your family whom I do not remove from my altar will have his eyes fail, and he will be heartbroken. And all your descendants will die in the prime of life.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: What is going to happen to your two sons, Hophni and Phinehas, will be a sign to you: Both of them will die on the same day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then I will appoint a faithful priest to serve me. He will do everything I want him to do. I will give him faithful descendants, and he will always live as my anointed one.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then anyone who is left from your household will bow down in front of him to get a coin or a loaf of bread and say, ‘Please appoint me to one of the priestly classes so that I may eat a piece of bread.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The boy Samuel was serving Yahweh under Eli. In those days a prophecy from Yahweh was rare; visions were infrequent.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One night Eli was lying down in his room. His eyesight had begun to fail so that he couldn’t see well.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The lamp in Elohim’s temple hadn’t gone out yet, and Samuel was asleep in the temple of Yahweh where the ark of Elohim was kept.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Yahweh called Samuel. “Here I am,” Samuel responded.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He ran to Eli and said, “Here I am. You called me.”
“I didn’t call you,” Eli replied. “Go back to bed.” So Samuel went back and lay down.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yahweh called Samuel again. Samuel got up, went to Eli, and said, “Here I am. You called me.”
“I didn’t call you, son,” he responded. “Go back to bed.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Samuel had no experience with Yahweh, because the word of Yahweh had not yet been revealed to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yahweh called Samuel a third time. Samuel got up, went to Eli, and said, “Here I am. You called me.”
Then Eli realized that Yahweh was calling the boy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Go, lie down,” Eli told Samuel. “When he calls you, say, ‘Speak, Yahweh. I’m listening.’” So Samuel went and lay down in his room.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yahweh came and stood there. He called as he had called the other times: “Samuel! Samuel!” And Samuel replied, “Speak. I’m listening.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Yahweh said to Samuel, “I am going to do something in Israel that will make the ears of everyone who hears it ring.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On that day I am going to do to Eli and his family everything I said from beginning to end.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I told him that I would hand down a permanent judgment against his household because he knew about his sons’ sin—that they were cursing God—but he didn’t try to stop them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That is why I have taken an oath concerning Eli’s family line: No offering or sacrifice will ever be able to make peace for the sins that Eli’s family committed.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Samuel remained in bed until morning. Then he opened the doors of Yahweh’s house. But Samuel was afraid to tell Eli about the vision.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then Eli called Samuel. “Samuel, my son!” he said.
“Here I am,” he responded.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “What did Yahweh tell you?” he asked. “Please don’t hide anything from me. May Elohim strike you dead if you hide anything he told you from me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So Samuel told Eli everything.
Eli replied, “He is Yahweh. May he do what he thinks is right.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Samuel grew up. Yahweh was with him and didn’t let any of his words go unfulfilled.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All Israel from Dan to Beersheba knew Samuel was Yahweh’s appointed prophet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yahweh continued to appear in Shiloh, since Yahweh revealed himself to Samuel in Shiloh through the word of Yahweh. And Samuel spoke to all Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Israel went to fight against the Philistines and camped near Ebenezer while the Philistines camped at Aphek.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Philistines organized their troops to meet Israel in battle. As the battle spread, the Philistines defeated Israel and killed about 4,000 soldiers in the field.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the troops came back to the camp, the leaders of Israel asked, “Why has Yahweh used the Philistines to defeat us today? Let’s get the ark of Yahweh’s promise from Shiloh so that he may be with us and save us from our enemies.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The troops sent some men who brought back the ark of the promise of Yahweh Tsebaoth—who is enthroned over the angels. Eli’s two sons, Hophni and Phinehas, came along with Elohim’s ark.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Yahweh’s ark came into the camp, all Israel shouted so loudly that the earth rang with echoes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As the Philistines heard the noise, they asked, “What’s all this shouting in the Hebrew camp?” The Philistines found out that Yahweh’s ark had come into the camp.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they were frightened and said, “A god has come into their camp.” They also said, “Oh no! Nothing like this has ever happened before.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We’re in trouble now! Who can save us from the power of these mighty gods? These are the gods who struck the Egyptians with every kind of plague in the desert.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Be strong, Philistines, and act like men, or else you will serve the Hebrews as they served you. Act like men and fight.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Philistines fought and defeated Israel. Every Israelite soldier fled to his tent. It was a major defeat in which 30,000 Israelite foot soldiers died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The ark of Elohim was captured. Both of Eli’s sons, Hophni and Phinehas, died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A man from the tribe of Benjamin ran from the front line of the battle. He went to Shiloh that day with his clothes torn and dirt on his head.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he arrived, Eli was sitting on a chair beside the road, watching. He was worried about the ark of Elohim. The man went into the city to tell the news. The whole city cried out.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hearing the cry, Eli asked, “What is this commotion?” So the man went quickly to tell Eli the news.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (Eli was 98 years old, and his eyesight had failed so that he couldn’t see.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The man told Eli, “I’m the one who came from the battle. I fled from the front line today.”
“What happened, son?” Eli asked.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Israel fled from the Philistines,” the messenger answered. “Our troops suffered heavy casualties. Your two sons, Hophni and Phinehas, also are dead, and the ark of Elohim has been captured.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the messenger mentioned the ark of Elohim, Eli fell from his chair backwards toward the gate. He broke his neck, and he died. (The man was old and heavy.) He had judged Israel for 40 years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His daughter-in-law, Phinehas’ wife, was pregnant. When she heard the news that the ark of Elohim had been captured and her father-in-law and her husband were dead, she went into labor prematurely and gave birth to a son.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As she was dying, the women helping her said, “Don’t be afraid. You’ve given birth to a son.” But she didn’t answer or pay attention.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She called the boy Ichabod [No Glory], saying, “Israel’s glory is gone,” because the ark of Elohim had been captured and because her father-in-law and her husband died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Israel’s glory is gone because the ark of Elohim has been captured,” she said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After the Philistines had captured the ark of Elohim, they brought it from Ebenezer to Ashdod.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They brought it into the temple of Dagon and placed it beside Dagon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Early the next day the people of Ashdod saw that Dagon had fallen forward on the ground in front of Yahweh’s ark. So they took Dagon and put him back in his place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the next morning they saw that Dagon had again fallen forward on the ground in front of Yahweh’s ark. Dagon’s head and his two hands were cut off and were lying on the temple’s threshold. The rest of Dagon’s body was intact.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is why the priests of Dagon and everyone else who comes into Dagon’s temple in Ashdod still don’t step on the temple’s threshold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yahweh dealt harshly with the people of Ashdod. He destroyed them by striking the people in the vicinity of Ashdod with tumors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the people of Ashdod realized what was happening, they said, “The ark of the Elohim of Israel must not stay with us, because their Elohim is dealing harshly with us and our god Dagon.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The people of Ashdod called together all the Philistine rulers. “What should we do with the ark of the Elohim of Israel?” they asked.
“The ark of the Elohim of Israel must be taken to Gath,” the rulers said. So the people took the ark of the Elohim of Israel there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But after they had moved it, Yahweh threw the city into a great panic: He struck all the important and unimportant people in the city, and they were covered with tumors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the people of Gath sent the ark of Elohim to Ekron. But when the ark of Elohim came to Ekron, the people of Ekron cried out, “They brought the ark of the Elohim of Israel here to kill us.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They called together all the Philistine rulers. “Send the ark of the Elohim of Israel away,” they said. “Let it go back to its own place so that it won’t kill us or our people.” There was a fear of death throughout the city, where Elohim dealt with them very harshly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people who didn’t die were struck with tumors. So the cry of the city went up to heaven.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The ark of Yahweh had been in Philistine territory seven months
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: when the Philistines called for priests and people skilled in explaining omens. The Philistines asked, “What should we do with the ark of Yahweh? Tell us how to return it to its proper place.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The priests answered, “If you’re returning the ark of the Elohim of Israel, don’t send it away empty, but by all means return it to its proper place with a guilt offering. Then you will be healed, and you will know why he would not turn his anger away from you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Philistines asked, “What kind of guilt offering should we give him?”
The priests answered, “Five gold tumors and five gold mice for the five Philistine rulers because all of you and your rulers suffer from the same plague.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Make models of your tumors and your mice which are destroying the country, and give glory to the Elohim of Israel. Maybe he will no longer be so hard on you, your gods, and your country.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Why should you be as stubborn as the Egyptians and their Pharaoh were? After he toyed with the Egyptians, didn’t they send the Israelites on their way?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now get a new cart ready for two dairy cows that have never been yoked. Hitch the cows to the cart. Take their calves away, and leave them in their stall.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Take the ark of Yahweh, and put it on the cart. Put the gold objects which you’re giving him as a guilt offering in a box beside the ark. Send the cart on its way,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but then watch where it goes. If it goes up the road to its own country toward Beth Shemesh, then this disaster is Yahweh’s doing. But if not, we’ll know it wasn’t his hand that struck us, but what happened to us was an accident.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people did this. They took two dairy cows, hitched them to a cart, and shut the calves in the stall.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They put the ark of Yahweh and the box containing the gold mice and the models of their hemorrhoids on the cart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The cows went straight up the road to Beth Shemesh. Continually mooing, they stayed on the road and didn’t turn right or left. The rulers of the Philistines followed them to the border of Beth Shemesh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people of Beth Shemesh were harvesting wheat in the valley. When they looked up and saw the ark, they were overjoyed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The cart came into the field of Joshua of Beth Shemesh and stopped there by a large rock. The people chopped up the wood of the cart and sacrificed the cows as a burnt offering to Yahweh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (The Levites had already taken down from the cart the ark of Yahweh and the box which contained the gold objects and put them on the large rock.) The people of Beth Shemesh presented burnt offerings and sacrifices to Yahweh that day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After the five rulers of the Philistines saw this, they went back to Ekron that same day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The gold hemorrhoids which the Philistines sent as a guilt offering to Yahweh were for the cities of Ashdod, Gaza, Ashkelon, Gath, and Ekron.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the number of gold mice was the same as the number of Philistine cities belonging to the five rulers, including walled cities and farm villages. The large rock on which they put the ark of Yahweh is a witness. It is still there today in the field of Joshua of Beth Shemesh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Elohim struck down some of the people from Beth Shemesh because they looked inside the ark of Yahweh. He struck down 70 people. The people mourned because Yahweh struck them with such a great blow.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people of Beth Shemesh asked, “Who can stand before Yahweh, this holy Elohim? And to which people will he go when he leaves us?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They sent messengers to the people living at Kiriath Jearim to say, “The Philistines have brought back the ark of Yahweh. Come and take it back with you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The men of Kiriath Jearim came to take Yahweh’s ark and brought it into Abinadab’s house on the hill. They gave Abinadab’s son Eleazar the holy occupation of guarding Yahweh’s ark.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A long time passed after the ark came to stay at Kiriath Jearim. For 20 years the entire nation of Israel mournfully sought Yahweh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Samuel told the entire nation of Israel, “If you are returning to Yahweh wholeheartedly, get rid of the foreign gods you have, including the statues of the goddess Astarte. Make a commitment to Yahweh, and serve only him. Then he will rescue you from the Philistines.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Israelites got rid of the statues of Baal and Astarte and served only Yahweh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Samuel said, “Gather all the Israelites together at Mizpah, and I will pray to Yahweh for you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Israelites gathered together at Mizpah. They drew some water, poured it out in front of Yahweh, and fasted that day. They confessed, “We have sinned against Yahweh.” So Samuel judged Israel in Mizpah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Philistines heard that the Israelites had gathered at Mizpah, the Philistine rulers came to attack Israel. The Israelites heard about the Philistine plan and were afraid of them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Israelites said to Samuel, “Don’t turn a deaf ear to us! Don’t stop crying to Yahweh our Elohim for us! Ask him to save us from the Philistines!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Samuel took a lamb, one still feeding on milk, and sacrificed it as a burnt offering to Yahweh. Samuel cried to Yahweh on behalf of Israel, and Yahweh answered him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While Samuel was sacrificing the burnt offering, the Philistines came to fight against Israel. On that day Yahweh thundered loudly at the Philistines and threw them into such confusion that they were defeated by Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Israel’s soldiers left Mizpah, pursued the Philistines, and killed them as far as Beth Car.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Samuel took a rock and set it up between Mizpah and Shen. He named it Ebenezer [Rock of Help] and said, “Until now Yahweh has helped us.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The power of the Philistines was crushed, so they didn’t come into Israel’s territory again. Yahweh restrained the Philistines as long as Samuel lived.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The cities between Ekron and Gath which the Philistines took from Israel were returned to Israel. And Israel recovered the territory controlled by these cities from the Philistines. There was also peace between Israel and the Amorites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Samuel judged Israel as long as he lived.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Every year he went around to Bethel, Gilgal, and Mizpah in order to judge Israel in all those places.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he would return home to Ramah. There, too, he judged Israel. And in Ramah he built an altar to Yahweh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Samuel was old, he made his sons judges over Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The name of his firstborn son was Joel; the name of his second son was Abijah. They were judges in Beersheba.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons didn’t follow their father’s example but turned to dishonest ways of making money. They took bribes and denied people justice.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then all the leaders of Israel gathered together and came to Samuel at Ramah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They told him, “You’re old, and your sons aren’t following your example. Now appoint a king to judge us so that we will be like all the other nations.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Samuel considered it wrong for them to request a king to judge them. So Samuel prayed to Yahweh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yahweh told Samuel, “Listen to everything the people are saying to you. They haven’t rejected you; they’ve rejected me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They’re doing just what they’ve done since I took them out of Egypt—leaving me and serving other gods.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Listen to them now, but be sure to warn them and tell them about the rights of a king.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Samuel told the people who had asked him for a king everything Yahweh had said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Samuel said, “These are the rights of a king:
He will draft your sons, make them serve on his chariots and horses, and make them run ahead of his chariots.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He will appoint them to be his officers over 1,000 or over 50 soldiers, to plow his ground and harvest his crops, and to make weapons and equipment for his chariots.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He will take your daughters and have them make perfumes, cook, and bake.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He will take the best of your fields, vineyards, and olive orchards and give them to his officials.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He will take a tenth of your grain and wine and give it to his aids and officials.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He will take your male and female slaves, your best cattle, and your donkeys for his own use.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He will take a tenth of your flocks.
In addition, you will be his servants.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “When that day comes, you will cry out because of the king whom you have chosen for yourselves. Yahweh will not answer you when that day comes.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the people refused to listen to Samuel. They said, “No, we want a king!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then we, too, will be like all the other nations. Our king will judge us, lead us out to war, and fight our battles.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Samuel heard everything the people had to say, he reported it privately to Yahweh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yahweh told him, “Listen to them, and give them a king.”
Then Samuel told the people of Israel, “Go back to your own cities.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was a man from the tribe of Benjamin whose name was Kish. He was a son of Abiel, grandson of Zeror, and great-grandson of Becorath, whose father was Aphiah, a descendant of Benjamin. Kish was a powerful man.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He had a son named Saul, a handsome, young man. No man in Israel was more handsome than Saul. He stood a head taller than everyone else.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When some donkeys belonging to Saul’s father Kish were lost, Kish told Saul, “Take one of the servants with you, and go look for the donkeys.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They went through the mountains of Ephraim and the region of Shalisha without finding the donkeys. Then Saul and his servant went through the region of Shaalim, but the donkeys weren’t there. The men went through the territory of Benjamin but still didn’t find them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they came to the territory of Zuph, Saul told his servant who was with him, “Let’s go back, or my father will stop worrying about the donkeys and worry about us instead.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The servant responded, “There’s a man of Elohim in this city, a highly respected man. Everything he says is sure to happen. Let’s go there. Maybe he’ll tell us which way we should go.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “If we go,” Saul asked his servant, “what could we bring the man since the food in our sacks is gone? There’s no present we can bring the man of Elohim. What do we have?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The servant again answered Saul, “Look, here! I have one-tenth of an ounce of silver. I’ll give it to the man of Elohim. Then he’ll tell us where to find the donkeys.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (Formerly in Israel, when a person went to ask Elohim a question, he would say, “Come, let’s go to the seer,” because a person we now call a prophet used to be called a seer.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul told his servant, “That’s a good idea! Come on, let’s go.” They went to the city where the man of Elohim was.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As they were going up the hill to the city, they met girls coming out to get water. They asked the girls, “Is the seer here?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The girls answered, “He’s there ahead of you. Hurry! He just went into the city today since the people are offering a sacrifice on the worship site.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As you go into the city, you can find him before he goes to the worship site to eat. The people will not eat until he comes, since he blesses the sacrifice. Then those who are invited may eat. Go. You should be able to find him now.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Saul and his servant went to the city. As they entered it, Samuel was coming toward them on his way to the worship site.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, Yahweh had revealed the following message to Samuel one day before Saul came:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “About this time tomorrow I will send you a man from the territory of Benjamin. Anoint him to be ruler of my people Israel. He will save my people from the Philistines because I’ve seen my people’s suffering and their cry has come to me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Samuel noticed Saul, Yahweh told him, “There’s the man I told you about. This man will govern my people.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul approached Samuel inside the gateway and said, “Please tell me where the seer’s house is.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Samuel replied, “I’m the seer. Go ahead of me to the worship site. You will eat with me today. In the morning I’ll let you go after I tell you all that’s on your mind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Don’t trouble yourself about the donkeys that were lost three days ago because they’ve been found. Who will have all that is desirable in Israel? Won’t it be you and your father’s family?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul replied, “I am a man from the tribe of Benjamin, the smallest tribe of Israel. My family is the most insignificant of all the families of the tribe of Benjamin. So why are you saying such things to me?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Samuel brought Saul and his servant to the banquet hall and had them sit at the head of the guests—about 30 people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Samuel said to the cook, “Bring me the portion of the sacrificial meat that I gave you and told you to put aside.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the cook picked up the leg and thigh and laid it in front of Saul. Samuel said, “This was kept in order to be laid in front of you. Eat it. When I invited people to the feast, I set it aside for you.” Saul ate with Samuel that day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they left the worship site for the city. They spread blankets on the roof for Saul, and he slept there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At dawn Samuel called to Saul on the roof, “Get up! It’s time for me to send you away.” Saul got up, and both he and Samuel went outside.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As they were going toward the city limits, Samuel told Saul, “Have the servant go ahead of you.” (He went ahead.) “But you stay here, and I will tell you Elohim’s word.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Samuel took a flask of olive oil, poured it on Saul’s head, kissed him, and said, “Yahweh has anointed you to be ruler of his people Israel. You will rule his people and save them from all their enemies. This will be the sign that Yahweh has anointed you to be ruler of his people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When you leave me today, two men will be at Rachel’s grave on the border of Benjamin at Zelzah. They’ll tell you, ‘We’ve found the donkeys you went looking for. Your father no longer cares about them. Instead, he’s worried about you. He keeps asking, “What can I do to find my son?”’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Keep going until you come to the oak tree at Tabor. There you will find three men on their way to worship Elohim at Bethel: One will be carrying three young goats, one will be carrying three loaves of bread, and one will be carrying a full wineskin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They will greet you and give you two loaves of bread, which you should accept from them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After that, you will come to the hill of Elohim, where the Philistines have a military post. When you arrive at the city, you will meet a group of prophets prophesying as they come from the worship site. They will be led by men playing a harp, a tambourine, a flute, and a lyre.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Ruach Yahweh will come over you. You will be a different person while you prophesy with them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When these signs happen to you, do what you must, because Elohim is with you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Go ahead of me to Gilgal. Then I will come to sacrifice burnt offerings and make fellowship offerings. Wait seven days until I come to tell you what to do.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Saul turned around to leave Samuel, Elohim changed Saul’s attitude. That day all these signs happened.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Saul came to the hill, a group of prophets came to meet him, and the Ruach Elohim came over him. He prophesied with them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When all who had known him before saw how he prophesied with the prophets, the people asked one another, “What has happened to the son of Kish? Is Saul one of the prophets?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But a man from that place asked, “But who’s the chief prophet?” So it became a proverb: “Is Saul one of the prophets?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And when he had finished prophesying, he came to the worship site.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Saul’s uncle asked him and his servant, “Where did you go?”
Saul answered, “To look for the donkeys, and when we couldn’t find them, we went to Samuel.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul’s uncle said, “Please tell me what Samuel said to you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “He assured us the donkeys had been found,” Saul answered his uncle. But Saul didn’t tell him what Samuel said about his becoming king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Samuel called the people to come into the presence of Yahweh at Mizpah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said to the Israelites, “This is what Yahweh Elohim of Israel says: I brought Israel out of Egypt and rescued you from the power of the Egyptians and all the kings who were oppressing you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But now you have rejected your Elohim, who saves you from all your troubles and distresses. You said, ‘No! Place a king over us.’ Now then, stand in front of Yahweh by your tribes and family groups.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Samuel had all the tribes of Israel come forward, the tribe of Benjamin was chosen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he had the tribe of Benjamin come forward by families, the family of Matri was chosen. Then Saul, the son of Kish, was chosen. They looked for him but couldn’t find him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They asked Yahweh again, “Has he arrived here yet?”
Yahweh answered, “He’s hiding among the baggage.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They ran and got him from there. As he stood among the people, he was a head taller than everyone else.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Samuel asked the people, “Do you see whom Yahweh has chosen? There is no one like him among all the people.”
Then all the people shouted, “Long live the king!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Samuel explained the laws concerning kingship to the people. He wrote the laws on a scroll, which he placed in front of Yahweh. Then Samuel sent the people back to their homes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul also went home to Gibeah. With him went some soldiers whose hearts Elohim had touched.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, some good-for-nothing people asked, “How can this man save us?” They despised him and wouldn’t bring him presents, but he didn’t respond.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Nahash of Ammon was severely oppressing the tribes of Gad and Reuben. He would poke out everyone’s right eye and allow no one to rescue Israel. There was no one among the Israelites east of the Jordan River whose right eye King Nahash of Ammon had not poked out. However, seven thousand men had escaped from the Ammonites and gone to Jabesh Gilead. About a month later Nahash the Ammonite blockaded Jabesh Gilead. All the men of Jabesh said to Nahash, “Make a treaty with us, and we’ll serve you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nahash the Ammonite responded, “I’ll make a treaty with you on this one condition: I’ll poke out everyone’s right eye and bring disgrace on all Israel.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The leaders of Jabesh told him, “Give us seven days so that we can send messengers throughout the territory of Israel. And if there’s no one to save us, we’ll surrender to you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The messengers came to Saul’s town, Gibeah. When they told the people the news, the people cried loudly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Just then Saul was coming from the field behind some oxen. “Why are these people crying?” Saul asked. So they told him the news about the men of Jabesh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he heard this news, the Ruach Elohim came over him, and he became very angry.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul took a pair of oxen, cut them in pieces, and sent them by messengers throughout the territory of Israel with the following message: “This is what will be done to the oxen of anyone who doesn’t follow Saul and Samuel into battle.” So the people became terrified by Yahweh, and they came out united behind Saul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Saul counted them at Bezek, there were 300,000 troops from Israel and 30,000 troops from Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They told the messengers who had come, “This is what you are to say to the men of Jabesh Gilead: ‘Tomorrow, by the time the sun gets hot, you will be rescued.’” When the men of Jabesh received the message, they were overjoyed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They said to Nahash, “Tomorrow we’ll surrender to you, and you may do to us whatever you think is right.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The next day Saul arranged the army in three divisions. They came into the Ammonite camp during the morning hours and continued to defeat the Ammonites until it got hot that day. The survivors were so scattered that no two of them were left together.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the people asked Samuel, “Who said that Saul shouldn’t rule us? Let us have them, and we’ll kill them.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Saul said, “No one will be killed today, because today Yahweh saved Israel.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Samuel told the troops, “Come, let’s go to Gilgal and there acknowledge Saul’s kingship.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then all the troops went to Gilgal, and there in Yahweh’s presence, they confirmed Saul as their king. There they sacrificed fellowship offerings to Yahweh. Saul and all of Israel’s soldiers celebrated.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Samuel said to all Israel, “I have listened to everything you have said to me and appointed a king over you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And now, here is the king who will lead you. I am old and gray, but my sons are with you. I have led you from my youth until this day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Here I am. Testify against me in front of Yahweh and in front of his anointed king. Did I take anyone’s ox? Did I take anyone’s donkey? Did I cheat or oppress anyone? Did I take a bribe from anyone to look the other way? If so, I will give it all back.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They answered, “You didn’t cheat us, oppress us, or take anything from anyone.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Samuel told them, “Yahweh is a witness to what you’ve said, and his anointed king is a witness today that you’ve found nothing in my hands.”
“He is a witness,” they answered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Samuel told the people, “Yahweh appointed Moses and Aaron and brought your ancestors out of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, stand up while I put you on trial in front of Yahweh and cite all the righteous things Yahweh did for you and your ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When your ancestors went with Jacob to Egypt and were oppressed, they cried out to Yahweh, who sent Moses and Aaron to bring them out of Egypt. Yahweh settled them in this place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But they forgot Yahweh their Elohim. So he handed them over to Sisera, who was the commander of the army of Hazor, to the Philistines, and to the king of Moab. All of them fought against your ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they cried out to Yahweh and said, ‘We have sinned. We have abandoned Yahweh and served other gods and goddesses—the Baals and the Astartes. But rescue us from our enemies now, and we will serve you.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Then Yahweh sent Jerubbaal, Bedan, Jephthah, and Samuel and rescued you from your enemies on every side so that you could live securely.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when you saw King Nahash of Ammon coming to attack you, you told me, ‘No, a king should rule over us,’ though Yahweh your Elohim was your king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Now, here is the king you have chosen, the one you asked for. See, Yahweh has put a king over you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If you fear Yahweh, serve him, obey him, and don’t rebel against what Yahweh says, then you and your king will follow Yahweh your Elohim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if you don’t obey Yahweh, if you rebel against what Yahweh says, then Yahweh will be against you as he was against your ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now then, stand still and watch this great thing Yahweh is going to do right before your eyes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Isn’t the wheat being harvested today? I will call on Yahweh, and he’ll send thunder and rain. Then you will realize what a wicked thing you did in Yahweh’s presence when you asked for a king.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Samuel called on Yahweh. That day Yahweh sent thunder and rain so that all the people feared Yahweh and Samuel very much.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the people pleaded with Samuel, “Pray to Yahweh your Elohim for us so that we will not die. We have added another evil thing to all our other sins by asking for a king.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Don’t be afraid,” Samuel told the people. “You did do all these evil things. But don’t turn away from Yahweh. Instead, serve Yahweh wholeheartedly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Don’t turn away to follow other gods. They can’t help or rescue you, because they don’t exist.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For the sake of his great name, Yahweh will not abandon his people, because Yahweh wants to make you his people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It would be unthinkable for me to sin against Yahweh by failing to pray for you. I will go on teaching you the way that is good and right.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Fear Yahweh, and serve him sincerely. Consider the great things he did for you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if you go on doing what is evil, you and your king will be wiped out.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul was thirty years old when he became king, and he was king of Israel forty-two years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul chose 3,000 men from Israel; 2,000 of them were stationed with Saul at Michmash and in the mountains of Bethel, and 1,000 were stationed with Jonathan at Gibeah in Benjamin. But the rest of the people he sent home.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jonathan defeated the Philistine troops at Geba, and the Philistines heard about it. With the sounding of the ram’s horn throughout the land, Saul announced, “Listen, Hebrews!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (So all Israel listened.) “I, Saul, have defeated the Philistine troops, and now Israel has become offensive to the Philistines!” All the troops rallied behind Saul at Gilgal.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Philistines assembled to fight against Israel. They had 30,000 chariots, 6,000 horsemen, and as many soldiers as the sand on the seashore. They camped at Michmash, east of Beth Aven.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Israelites saw they were in trouble because the army was hard-pressed, they hid in caves, in thorny thickets, among rocks, in pits, and in cisterns.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some Hebrews crossed the Jordan River into the territory of Gad and Gilead. But Saul remained in Gilgal, and all the people who followed him trembled in fear.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He waited seven days, the time set by Samuel. But Samuel had not come to Gilgal, and the troops began to scatter.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Saul said, “Bring me the animals for the burnt offering and the fellowship offerings.” So he sacrificed the burnt offering.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As he finished sacrificing the burnt offering, Samuel came, and Saul went to greet him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Samuel asked, “What have you done?”
Saul replied, “I saw the troops were scattering. You didn’t come when you said you would, and the Philistines were assembling at Michmash.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I thought, ‘Now, the Philistines will come against me at Gilgal, but I haven’t sought Yahweh’s favor.’ I felt pressured into sacrificing the burnt offering.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “You did a foolish thing,” Samuel told Saul. “You didn’t follow the command of Yahweh your Elohim. If you had, Yahweh would have established your kingdom over Israel permanently.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But now your kingdom will not last. Yahweh has searched for a man after his own heart. Yahweh has appointed him as ruler of his people, because you didn’t follow the command of Yahweh.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Samuel left Gilgal. The rest of the people followed Saul to meet the soldiers. They went from Gilgal to Gibeah in Benjamin, where Saul counted the troops who were still with him—about 600 men.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul, his son Jonathan, and the troops who were with them stayed at Geba in Benjamin while the Philistines camped at Michmash.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Raiding parties left the Philistine camp in three columns. One column turned onto the road to Ophrah to the region of Shual.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Another column turned onto the road to Beth Horon. And one turned onto the road toward the region that overlooks the valley of Zeboim and the desert.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: No blacksmith could be found in the entire land of Israel. In this way the Philistines kept the Hebrews from making swords and spears.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Everyone in Israel had to go to the Philistines to sharpen the blade of his plow, his mattock, ax, or sickle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The price was a pim for plow blades and mattocks, and one-tenth of an ounce of silver to sharpen a mattock or set a metal point on a cattle-prod.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So on the day of battle, not one sword or spear could be found among all the troops who were with Saul and Jonathan. But Saul and his son Jonathan had them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, Philistine troops had gone out to the pass at Michmash.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One day Saul’s son Jonathan said to his armorbearer, “Let’s go to the Philistine military post on the other side.” But Jonathan didn’t tell his father he was going.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul was staying on the outskirts of Gibeah under a pomegranate tree at Migron. He had with him about 600 men
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
in addition to Ahijah, the son of Ichabod’s brother Ahitub, who was the son of Phinehas and the grandson of Eli, Yahweh’s priest at Shiloh. Ahijah was wearing the priestly ephod.
The troops didn’t know Jonathan had left.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was a cliff on each side of the mountain pass where Jonathan searched for a way to cross over to attack the Philistine military post. The name of one cliff was Bozez, and the name of the other was Seneh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One cliff stood like a pillar on the north facing Michmash, the other stood south facing Geba.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jonathan said to his armorbearer, “Let’s go to the military post of these uncircumcised people. Maybe Yahweh will act on our behalf. Yahweh can win a victory with a few men as well as with many.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His armorbearer answered him, “Do whatever you have in mind. Go ahead! I agree with you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jonathan continued, “Listen, we’ll cross over to the Philistines and show ourselves to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If they say to us, ‘Stay where you are until we come to you,’ then we’ll stay where we are and not go up to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if they say to us, ‘Come up here,’ then we’ll go up, because that will be our sign that Yahweh has handed them over to us.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So both of them showed themselves to the Philistine troops. The Philistines said, “Look, some Hebrews are coming out of the holes they were hiding in.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Come up here,” the men of the military post said to Jonathan and his armorbearer. “We have something to show you.”
Jonathan told his armorbearer, “Follow me up to the military post because Yahweh has handed the troops over to Israel.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jonathan climbed up the cliff, and his armorbearer followed him. Jonathan struck down the Philistines. His armorbearer, who was behind him, finished killing them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In their first slaughter Jonathan and his armorbearer killed about twenty men within about a hundred yards.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was panic among the army in the field and all the troops in the military post. The raiding party also trembled in fear. The earth shook, and there was a panic sent from Elohim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul’s watchmen at Gibeah in Benjamin could see the crowd in the Philistine camp dispersing in all directions.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Look around,” Saul told the troops who were with him, “and see who has left our camp.” They looked and found that Jonathan and his armorbearer were not there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Saul said to Ahijah, “Bring the priestly ephod,” because Ahijah carried the ephod in front of Israel that day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While Saul was talking to the priest, the confusion in the Philistine camp grew worse and worse. Then Saul said to the priest, “Remove your hand from the ephod.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul and all the troops with him assembled and went into battle. They found Philistine soldiers killing their fellow soldiers in wild confusion.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Hebrews who had been with the Philistines before this and had been stationed in the camp now joined the Israelites who were with Saul and Jonathan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When all the men of Israel who had been hiding in the mountains of Ephraim heard that the Philistines were fleeing, they also pursued the Philistines in battle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So Yahweh saved Israel that day.
Now, the battle moved beyond Beth Aven.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Israel’s soldiers were driven hard that day. Saul made the troops swear, “Cursed is anyone who eats food before the evening comes and before I’ve gotten revenge on my enemies.” So none of his troops tasted any food.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The entire land had honeycombs, and there was honey on the ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the troops entered the woods, the honey was flowing. But no one put his hand to his mouth, because the troops were afraid of violating their oath.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jonathan hadn’t heard that his father forced the troops to take an oath. So he stretched out the tip of the staff he had in his hand and dipped it in the honeycomb. When he put it to his mouth, his eyes lit up.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then one of the soldiers told him, “Your father forced the troops to take a solemn oath: ‘Cursed is anyone who eats food today.’”
Now, the army was exhausted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jonathan answered, “My father has brought trouble to the country. See how my eyes lit up when I tasted a little of this honey?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If only the troops had eaten some of the enemies’ food, which they found today. We would have killed more Philistines.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That day they struck down the Philistines from Michmash to Aijalon, but the troops were thoroughly exhausted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the troops seized the Philistines’ belongings. They took sheep, cows, and calves, and butchered them on the ground. The troops ate the meat with blood still in it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Some soldiers told Saul, “The troops are sinning against Yahweh by eating meat with blood in it.”
Saul replied, “You have been unfaithful. Roll a large rock over to me now.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then Saul said, “Spread out through the troops, and tell them, ‘Each of you, bring me your ox or your sheep, and butcher it here, and eat. But don’t sin against Yahweh by eating meat with blood in it.’”
So each of the soldiers brought his ox with him that night and butchered it there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Saul built an altar to Yahweh; it was the first time he had built an altar to Yahweh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Saul said to his men, “Let’s attack the Philistines tonight and take their possessions until the light of dawn. And let’s not leave any of them alive.”
“Do whatever you think is best,” they responded.
But the priest said, “Let’s consult Elohim first.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Saul asked Elohim, “Should I attack the Philistines? Will you hand them over to Israel?” But he received no answer that day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Saul ordered all the leaders of the troops, “Come here! Find out what sin was committed today.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I solemnly swear, as Yahweh and Savior of Israel lives, even if it is my son Jonathan who did it, he must die.” But not one of the soldiers replied.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Saul told all Israel, “You stand on one side, and my son Jonathan and I will stand on the other side.”
“Do whatever you think is best,” the troops responded to Saul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Saul said to Yahweh, “O Elohim of Israel, why didn’t you answer me today? If this sin is mine or my son Jonathan’s, Yahweh Elohim of Israel, let the priest draw Urim. But if it is in your people Israel, let him draw Thummim.” Jonathan and Saul were chosen, and the people were freed from guilt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Choose between me and my son Jonathan,” Saul said. Then Jonathan was chosen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Tell me,” Saul asked Jonathan. “What did you do?”
So Jonathan told him, “I tasted a little honey on the tip of the staff I had in my hand. And for that I am to die?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul said, “May Elohim do worse things to me than are in this curse if you do not die, Jonathan!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The troops asked Saul, “Should Jonathan die after he has won this great victory in Israel? That would be unthinkable! We solemnly swear, as Yahweh lives, not a single hair of his head will fall to the ground, because he has done this with Elohim’s help today.” So the troops rescued Jonathan from death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Saul stopped pursuing the Philistines. So the Philistines returned to their own land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Saul had taken over the kingdom of Israel, he fought against his enemies on every side—against Moab, the Ammonites, Edom, the kings of Zobah, and the Philistines. Wherever he turned, he was victorious.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He acted forcefully and defeated Amalek. He rescued Israel from the enemies who looted their possessions.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul’s sons were Jonathan, Ishvi, and Malchishua. The names of his two daughters were Merab (the firstborn daughter) and Michal (the younger daughter).
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The name of Saul’s wife was Ahinoam, the daughter of Ahimaaz. The name of the commander of his army was Abner, the son of Saul’s uncle Ner.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Kish (Saul’s father) and Ner (Abner’s father) were the sons of Abiel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was intense warfare with the Philistines as long as Saul lived. Whenever any warrior or any skilled fighting man came to Saul’s attention, Saul would enlist him in the army.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Samuel told Saul, “Yahweh sent me to anoint you king of his people Israel. Now listen to Yahweh’s words.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what Yahweh Tsebaoth says: I will punish Amalek for what they did to Israel. They blocked Israel’s way after the Israelites came from Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now go and attack Amalek. Claim everything they have for God by destroying it. Don’t spare them, but kill men and women, infants and children, cows and sheep, camels and donkeys.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul organized the troops, and he counted them at Telaim: 200,000 foot soldiers and 10,000 men from Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul went to the city of Amalek and set an ambush in the valley.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Saul said to the Kenites, “Get away from the Amalekites so that I won’t destroy you with them. You were kind to all the Israelites when they came from Egypt.” So the Kenites left the Amalekites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul attacked the Amalekites from Havilah to Shur, east of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He captured King Agag of Amalek alive. But he claimed all the people for God by destroying them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul and the army spared Agag and the best sheep and cows, the fattened animals, the lambs, and all the best property. The army refused to claim them for God by destroying them. But everything that was worthless and weak the army did claim for God and destroy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Yahweh spoke to Samuel:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I regret that I made Saul king. He turned away from me and did not carry out my instructions.” Samuel was angry, and he prayed to Yahweh all night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Early in the morning he got up to meet Saul. Samuel was told, “Saul went to Carmel to set up a monument in his honor. Then he left there and went to Gilgal.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Samuel came to Saul, who said, “Yahweh bless you. I carried out Yahweh’s instructions.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
However, Samuel asked,
“But what is this sound of sheep in my ears
    and this sound of cows that I hear?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul answered, “The army brought them from the Amalekites. They spared the best sheep and cows to sacrifice to Yahweh your Elohim. But the rest they claimed for God and destroyed.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Be quiet,” Samuel told Saul, “and let me tell you what Yahweh told me last night.”
“Speak,” Saul replied.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Samuel said, “Even though you don’t consider yourself great, you were the head of Israel’s tribes. Yahweh anointed you king of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Yahweh sent you on a mission. He said, ‘Claim those sinners, the Amalekites, for me by destroying them. Wage war against them until they’re wiped out.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Why didn’t you obey Yahweh? Why have you taken their belongings and done what Yahweh considers evil?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “But I did obey Yahweh,” Saul told Samuel. “I went where Yahweh sent me, brought back King Agag of Amalek, and claimed the Amalekites for God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The army took some of their belongings—the best sheep and cows were claimed for God—in order to sacrifice to Yahweh your Elohim in Gilgal.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then Samuel said,
“Is Yahweh as delighted with burnt offerings and sacrifices
    as he would be with your obedience?
To follow instructions is better than to sacrifice.
To obey is better than sacrificing the fat of rams.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The sin of black magic is rebellion.
    Wickedness and idolatry are arrogance.
Because you rejected the word of Yahweh,
    he rejects you as king.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Saul told Samuel, “I have sinned by not following Yahweh’s command or your instructions. I was afraid of the people and listened to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now please forgive my sin and come back with me so that I may worship Yahweh.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Samuel told Saul, “I will not go back with you because you rejected what Yahweh told you. So Yahweh rejects you as king of Israel.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Samuel turned to leave, Saul grabbed the hem of his robe, and it tore.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Samuel told him, “Yahweh has torn the kingdom of Israel from you today. He has given it to your neighbor who is better than you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In addition, the Glory of Israel does not lie or change his mind, because he is not a mortal who changes his mind.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul replied, “I have sinned! Now please honor me in front of the leaders of my people and in front of Israel. Come back with me, and let me worship Yahweh your Elohim.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Samuel turned and followed Saul, and Saul worshiped Yahweh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Bring me King Agag of Amalek,” Samuel said.
Agag came to him trembling. “Surely, the bitterness of death is past,” Agag said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Samuel said, “As your sword made women childless, so your mother will be made childless among women.” And Samuel cut Agag in pieces in the presence of Yahweh at Gilgal.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Samuel went to Ramah, and Saul went to his home at Gibeah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Samuel didn’t see Saul again before he died, though Samuel mourned over Saul. And Yahweh regretted that he had made Saul king of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yahweh asked Samuel, “How long are you going to mourn for Saul now that I have rejected him as king of Israel? Fill a flask with olive oil and go. I’m sending you to Jesse in Bethlehem because I’ve selected one of his sons to be king.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“How can I go?” Samuel asked. “When Saul hears about it, he’ll kill me.”
Yahweh said, “Take a heifer with you and say, ‘I’ve come to sacrifice to Yahweh.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Invite Jesse to the sacrifice. I will reveal to you what you should do, and you will anoint for me the one I point out to you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Samuel did what Yahweh told him. When he came to Bethlehem, the leaders of the city, trembling with fear, greeted him and said, “May peace be with you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Greetings,” he replied, “I have come to sacrifice to Yahweh. Perform the ceremonies to make yourselves holy, and come with me to the sacrifice.” He performed the ceremonies for Jesse and his sons and invited them to the sacrifice.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they came, he saw Eliab and thought, “Certainly, here in Yahweh’s presence is his anointed king.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Yahweh told Samuel, “Don’t look at his appearance or how tall he is, because I have rejected him. Elohim does not see as humans see. Humans look at outward appearances, but Yahweh looks into the heart.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jesse called Abinadab and brought him to Samuel. But Samuel said, “Yahweh has not chosen this one either.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jesse had Shammah come to Samuel. “Yahweh has not chosen this one either,” Samuel said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jesse brought seven more of his sons to Samuel, but Samuel told Jesse, “Yahweh has not chosen any of these.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Are these all the sons you have?”
“There’s still the youngest one,” Jesse answered. “He’s tending the sheep.”
Samuel told Jesse, “Send someone to get him. We won’t continue until he gets here.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jesse sent for him. He had a healthy complexion, attractive eyes, and a handsome appearance. Yahweh said, “Go ahead, anoint him. He is the one.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Samuel took the flask of olive oil and anointed David in the presence of his brothers. The Ruach Yahweh came over David and stayed with him from that day on. Then Samuel left for Ramah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, the Ruach Yahweh had left Saul, and an evil spirit from Yahweh tormented him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul’s officials told him, “An evil spirit from Elohim is tormenting you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Your Majesty, why don’t you command us to look for a man who can play the lyre well? When the evil spirit from Elohim comes to you, he’ll strum a tune, and you’ll feel better.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul told his officials, “Please find me a man who can play well and bring him to me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One of the officials said, “I know one of Jesse’s sons from Bethlehem who can play well. He’s a courageous man and a warrior. He has a way with words, he is handsome, and Yahweh is with him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul sent messengers to Jesse to say, “Send me your son David, who is with the sheep.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jesse took six bushels of bread, a full wineskin, and a young goat and sent them with his son David to Saul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David came to Saul and served him. Saul loved him very much and made David his armorbearer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul sent this message to Jesse, “Please let David stay with me because I have grown fond of him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whenever Elohim’s spirit came to Saul, David took the lyre and strummed a tune. Saul got relief from his terror and felt better, and the evil spirit left him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Philistines assembled their armies for war. They assembled at Socoh, which is in Judah, and camped between Socoh and Azekah at Ephes Dammim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Saul and the army of Israel assembled and camped in the Elah Valley. They formed a battle line to fight the Philistines.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Philistines were stationed on a hill on one side, and the Israelites were stationed on a hill on the other side. There was a ravine between the two of them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Philistine army’s champion came out of their camp. His name was Goliath from Gath. He was ten feet tall.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He had a bronze helmet on his head, and he wore a bronze coat of armor scales weighing 125 pounds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On his legs he had bronze shin guards and on his back a bronze javelin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The shaft of his spear was like the beam used by weavers. The head of his spear was made of 15 pounds of iron. The man who carried his shield walked ahead of him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Goliath stood and called to the Israelites, “Why do you form a battle line? Am I not a Philistine, and aren’t you Saul’s servants? Choose a man, and let him come down to fight me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If he can fight me and kill me, then we will be your slaves. But if I overpower him and kill him, then you will be our slaves and serve us.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Philistine added, “I challenge the Israelite battle line today. Send out a man so that we can fight each other.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Saul and all the Israelites heard what this Philistine said, they were gripped with fear.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David was a son of a man named Jesse from the region of Ephrath and the city of Bethlehem in Judah. Jesse had eight sons, and in Saul’s day he was an old man.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jesse’s three oldest sons joined Saul’s army for the battle. The firstborn was Eliab, the second was Abinadab, the third was Shammah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and David was the youngest. The three oldest joined Saul’s army.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David went back and forth from Saul’s camp to Bethlehem, where he tended his father’s flock.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Each morning and evening for 40 days, the Philistine came forward and made his challenge.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jesse told his son David, “Take this half-bushel of roasted grain and these ten loaves of bread to your brothers. Take them to your brothers in the camp right away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And take these ten cheeses to the captain of the regiment. See how your brothers are doing, and bring back some news about them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They, along with Saul and all the soldiers of Israel, are in the Elah Valley fighting the Philistines.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David got up early in the morning and had someone else watch the sheep. He took the food and went, as Jesse ordered him. He went to the camp as the army was going out to the battle line shouting their war cry.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Israel and the Philistines formed their battle lines facing each other.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David left the supplies behind in the hands of the quartermaster, ran to the battle line, and greeted his brothers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While he was talking to them, the Philistine champion, Goliath from Gath, came from the battle lines of the Philistines. He repeated his words, and David heard them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When all the men of Israel saw Goliath, they fled from him because they were terrified.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The men of Israel said, “Did you see that man coming from the Philistine lines? He keeps coming to challenge Israel. The king will make the man who kills this Philistine very rich. He will give his daughter to that man to marry and elevate the social status of his family.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David asked the men who were standing near him, “What will be done for the man who kills this Philistine and gets rid of Israel’s disgrace? Who is this uncircumcised Philistine that he should challenge the army of Elohim Chay?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The soldiers repeated to David how the man who kills Goliath would be treated.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Eliab, David’s oldest brother, heard David talking to the men. Then Eliab became angry with David. “Why did you come here,” he asked him, “and with whom did you leave those few sheep in the wilderness? I know how overconfident and headstrong you are. You came here just to see the battle.”
verses.speaker: Narrator
