verses.text: “What have I done now?” David snapped at him. “Didn’t I merely ask a question?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He turned to face another man and asked the same question, and the other soldiers gave him the same answer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: What David said was overheard and reported to Saul, who then sent for him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David told Saul, “No one should be discouraged because of this. I will go and fight this Philistine.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul responded to David, “You can’t fight this Philistine. You’re just a boy, but he’s been a warrior since he was your age.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David replied to Saul, “I am a shepherd for my father’s sheep. Whenever a lion or a bear came and carried off a sheep from the flock,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I went after it, struck it, and rescued the sheep from its mouth. If it attacked me, I took hold of its mane, struck it, and killed it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have killed lions and bears, and this uncircumcised Philistine will be like one of them because he has challenged the army of Elohim Chay.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
David added, “Yahweh, who saved me from the lion and the bear, will save me from this Philistine.”
“Go,” Saul told David, “and may Yahweh be with you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul put his battle tunic on David; he put a bronze helmet on David’s head and dressed him in armor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David fastened Saul’s sword over his clothes and tried to walk, but he had never practiced doing this. “I can’t walk in these things,” David told Saul. “I’ve never had any practice doing this.” So David took all those things off.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He took his stick with him, picked out five smooth stones from the riverbed, and put them in his shepherd’s bag. With a sling in his hand, he approached the Philistine.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Philistine, preceded by the man carrying his shield, was coming closer and closer to David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Philistine got a good look at David, he despised him. After all, David was a young man with a healthy complexion and good looks.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Philistine asked David, “Am I a dog that you come to attack me with sticks?” So the Philistine called on his gods to curse David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Come on,” the Philistine told David, “and I’ll give your body to the birds.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David told the Philistine, “You come to me with sword and spear and javelin, but I come to you in the name of the Yahweh Tsebaoth, the Elohim of the army of Israel, whom you have insulted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Today Yahweh will hand you over to me. I will strike you down and cut off your head. And this day I will give the dead bodies of the Philistine army to the birds and the wild animals. The whole world will know that Israel has an Elohim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then everyone gathered here will know that Yahweh can save without sword or spear, because Yahweh determines every battle’s outcome. He will hand all of you over to us.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Philistine moved closer in order to attack, David quickly ran toward the opposing battle line to attack the Philistine.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David reached into his bag, took out a stone, hurled it from his sling, and struck the Philistine in the forehead. The stone sank into Goliath’s forehead, and he fell to the ground on his face.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So using only a sling and a stone, David proved to be stronger than the Philistine. David struck down and killed the Philistine, even though David didn’t have a sword in his hand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
David ran and stood over the Philistine. He took Goliath’s sword, pulled it out of its sheath, and made certain the Philistine was dead by cutting off his head.
When the Philistines saw their hero had been killed, they fled.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the soldiers of Israel and Judah rose up, shouted a battle cry, and pursued the Philistines as far as Gath and to the gates of Ekron. Wounded Philistines lay on the road to Shaaraim and all the way to Gath and Ekron.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Israelites came back from their pursuit of the Philistines, they looted all the goods in the Philistine camp.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David took the Philistine’s head and brought it to Jerusalem, but he kept Goliath’s armor in his tent.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As Saul watched David going out against the Philistine, he asked Abner, the commander of the army, “Abner, whose son is this young man?”
Abner answered, “I solemnly swear, as you live, Your Majesty, I don’t know.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king said, “Find out whose son this young man is.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David returned from killing the Philistine, Abner brought him to Saul. David had the Philistine’s head in his hand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Saul asked him, “Whose son are you, young man?”
“The son of your servant Jesse of Bethlehem,” David answered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David finished talking to Saul. After that, Jonathan became David’s closest friend. He loved David as much as he loved himself.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (From that day on Saul kept David as his servant and didn’t let him go back to his family.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jonathan made a pledge of mutual loyalty with David because he loved him as much as he loved himself.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jonathan took off the coat he had on and gave it to David along with his battle tunic, his sword, his bow, and his belt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David was successful wherever Saul sent him. Saul put him in charge of the fighting men. This pleased all the people, including Saul’s officials.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As they arrived, David was returning from a campaign against the Philistines. Women from all of Israel’s cities came to meet King Saul. They sang and danced, accompanied by tambourines, joyful music, and triangles.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The women who were celebrating sang,
“Saul has defeated thousands
    but David tens of thousands!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul became very angry because he considered this saying to be insulting. “To David they credit tens of thousands,” he said, “but to me they credit only a few thousand. The only thing left for David is my kingdom.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From that day on Saul kept an eye on David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The next day an evil spirit from Elohim seized Saul. He began to prophesy in his house while David strummed a tune on the lyre as he did every day. Now, Saul had a spear in his hand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He raised the spear and thought, “I’ll nail David to the wall.” But David got away from him twice.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul was afraid of David, because Yahweh was with David but had left Saul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he kept David away. He made David captain of a regiment. David led the troops out to battle and back again.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He was successful in everything he undertook because Yahweh was with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul noticed how very successful he was and became even more afraid of him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Everyone in Israel and Judah loved David, because he led them in and out of battle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Finally, Saul said to David, “Here is my oldest daughter Merab. I will give her to you as your wife if you prove yourself to be a warrior for me and fight Yahweh’s battles.” (Saul thought, “I must not lay a hand on him. Let the Philistines do that.”)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Who am I?” David asked Saul. “And how important are my relatives or my father’s family in Israel that I should be the king’s son-in-law?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when the time came to give Saul’s daughter Merab to David, she was married to Adriel from Meholah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, Saul’s daughter Michal fell in love with David. When Saul was told about it, the news pleased him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul thought, “I’ll give her to David. She will trap him, and the Philistines will get him.” So he said to David a second time, “You will now be my son-in-law.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul ordered his officers, “Talk to David in private. Tell him, ‘The king likes you, and all his officers are fond of you. Become the king’s son-in-law.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Saul’s officers made it a point to say this, David asked, “Do you think it’s easy to become the king’s son-in-law? I am a poor and unimportant person.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the officers told Saul what David had said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul replied, “Tell David, ‘The king doesn’t want any payment for the bride except 100 Philistine foreskins so that he can get revenge on his enemies.’” In this way Saul planned to have David fall into the hands of the Philistines.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When his officers told David this, David concluded that it was acceptable to become the king’s son-in-law. Before the time was up,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David and his men went out and struck down 200 Philistines. David brought the foreskins, and they counted them out for the king so that David could become the king’s son-in-law. Then Saul gave him his daughter Michal as his wife.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul realized that Yahweh was with David and that his daughter Michal loved David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Saul was even more afraid of David, and so Saul became David’s constant enemy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Philistine generals still went out to fight Israel. But whenever they went out to fight, David was more successful than the rest of Saul’s officers. So David gained a good reputation.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul told his son Jonathan and all his officers to kill David. But Saul’s son Jonathan was very fond of David,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: so he reported to David, “My father Saul is trying to kill you. Please be careful tomorrow morning. Go into hiding, and stay out of sight.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I’ll go out and stand beside my father in the field where you’ll be. I’ll speak with my father about you. If I find out anything, I’ll tell you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jonathan spoke well of David to his father Saul. “You should not commit a sin against your servant David,” he said. “He hasn’t sinned against you. Instead, he has done some very fine things for you:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He risked his life and killed the Philistine Goliath, and Yahweh gave all Israel a great victory. When you saw it, you rejoiced. Why then should you sin by shedding David’s innocent blood for no reason?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul listened to Jonathan, and he promised, “I solemnly swear, as Yahweh lives, he will not be killed.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jonathan told David all of this. Then Jonathan took David to Saul. So David was returned to his former status in Saul’s court.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When war broke out again, David went to fight the Philistines. He defeated them so decisively that they fled from him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then an evil spirit from Yahweh came over Saul while he was sitting in his house with his spear in his hand. David was strumming a tune.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul tried to nail David to the wall with his spear. But David dodged it, and Saul’s spear struck the wall. David fled, escaping from Saul that night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul sent messengers to watch David’s house and kill him in the morning. But Michal, David’s wife, advised him, “If you don’t save yourself tonight, you’ll be dead tomorrow!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Michal lowered David through a window, and he ran away to escape.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Michal took some idols, laid them in the bed, put a goat-hair blanket at its head, and covered the idols with a garment.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Saul sent messengers to get David, Michal said, “He’s sick.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Saul sent the messengers back to see David themselves. Saul told them, “Bring him here to me in his bed so that I can kill him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The messengers came, and there in the bed were the idols with the goat-hair blanket at its head.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Saul asked Michal, “Why did you betray me by sending my enemy away so that he could escape?”
Michal answered, “He told me, ‘Let me go! Why should I kill you?’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David escaped and went to Samuel at Ramah. He told Samuel everything Saul had done to him. Then he and Samuel went to the pastures and lived there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When it was reported to Saul that David was in the pastures at Ramah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul sent messengers to get David. But when they saw a group of prophets prophesying with Samuel serving as their leader, the Ruach Elohim came over Saul’s messengers so that they also prophesied.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they told Saul about this, he sent other messengers, but they also prophesied. Saul even sent a third group of messengers, but they also prophesied.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then he went to Ramah himself. He went as far as the big cistern in Secu and asked the people, “Where are Samuel and David?”
He was told, “Over there in the pastures at Ramah.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As he went toward the pastures at Ramah, the Ruach Elohim came over him too. He continued his journey, prophesying until he came to the pastures at Ramah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He even took off his clothes as he prophesied in front of Samuel and lay there naked all day and all night. This is where the saying, “Is Saul one of the prophets?” came from.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David fled from the pastures at Ramah, came to Jonathan, and asked, “What have I done? What crime am I guilty of? What sin have I committed against your father that he’s trying to kill me?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jonathan answered, “That’s unthinkable! You’re not going to die! My father does nothing without telling me, whether it’s important or not. Why should my father hide this from me? It’s just not that way.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But David took an oath, saying, “Your father certainly knows that you support me, so he said to himself, ‘Jonathan must not know about this. It will bring him distress.’ But I solemnly swear, as Yahweh and you live, I’m only one step away from death.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jonathan said to David, “I’ll do whatever you say.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David replied, “Tomorrow is the New Moon Festival, when I should sit and eat at the king’s table. But let me go and hide in the countryside for two more nights.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If your father really misses me, tell him, ‘David repeatedly begged me to let him run to Bethlehem, his hometown, because his relatives are offering the annual sacrifice there.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If he says, ‘Good!’ then I will be safe. But if he gets really angry, then you’ll know for sure that he has decided to harm me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, be kind to me. After all, you forced me into an agreement with Yahweh. If I have committed any crime, kill me yourself. Why bother taking me to your father?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jonathan answered, “That’s unthinkable! If I knew for sure that my father had decided to harm you, I would have told you about it.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David asked, “Who will tell me whether or not your father gives you a harsh answer?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jonathan said, “Let’s go out into the country.” So they went out into the country.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “As Yahweh Elohim of Israel is my witness,” Jonathan continued, “I’ll find out in the next two or three days how my father feels about you. If he does feel kindly toward you, then I will send someone to tell you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If my father plans to harm you and I fail to tell you and send you away safely, may Yahweh harm me even more. May Yahweh be with you as he used to be with my father.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But as long as I live, promise me that you will show me kindness because of Yahweh. And even when I die,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: never stop being kind to my family. Yahweh will wipe each of David’s enemies off the face of the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At that time, if Jonathan’s name is cut off from David’s family, then may Yahweh punish David’s house.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Once again Jonathan swore an oath to David because of his love for David. He loved David as much as he loved himself.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Tomorrow is the New Moon Festival,” Jonathan told him, “and you will be missed when your seat is empty.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The day after tomorrow you will be missed even more. So go to the place where you hid on that other occasion, and stay by the rock.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will shoot three arrows from beside it toward a target.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then I will send out a boy and say, ‘Go, find the arrows.’ Now, if I tell the boy, ‘Look, the arrows are next to you; get them,’ then come back with me. You will be safe, and there will be no trouble. I swear it, as Yahweh lives.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if I tell the boy, ‘The arrows are next to you,’ then go, because Yahweh has sent you away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We have made a promise to each other, and Yahweh is a witness between you and me forever.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David hid in the countryside. When the New Moon Festival came, King Saul sat down to eat the festival meal.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He sat in his usual seat by the wall, while Jonathan stood. Abner sat beside Saul, but David’s place was empty.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul didn’t say anything that day, thinking, “Something has happened to him so that he’s unclean. He must be unclean.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But on the second day of the month, David’s place was still empty.
Saul asked his son Jonathan, “Why hasn’t Jesse’s son come to the meal either yesterday or today?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jonathan answered Saul, “David repeatedly begged me to let him go to Bethlehem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David said to me ‘Please let me go. Our relatives will offer a sacrifice in the city, and my brother ordered me to be there. If you will permit it, please let me go to see my brothers.’ This is why he hasn’t come to your banquet.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Saul got angry with Jonathan. “Son of a crooked and rebellious woman!” he called Jonathan. “I know you’ve sided with Jesse’s son. You have no shame. You act as if you are your mother’s son but not mine.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As long as Jesse’s son lives on earth, neither you nor your right to be king is secure. Now, send some men to bring him to me. He’s a dead man!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jonathan asked his father, “Why should he be killed? What has he done?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul raised his spear to strike him. Then Jonathan knew his father was determined to kill David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jonathan got up from the table very angry and ate nothing that second day of the month. He was worried sick about David because Jonathan had been humiliated by his own father.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the morning Jonathan went out to the country to the place he and David had agreed on. Jonathan had a young boy with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Run,” he told the boy, “please find the arrows I shoot.”
The boy ran, and Jonathan shot the arrow over him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the boy reached the place where Jonathan’s arrow had landed, Jonathan called after him, “The arrows are next to you!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jonathan added, “Quick! Hurry up! Don’t stand there!” Jonathan’s young servant gathered the arrows and came to his master.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The boy had no idea what was going on, but Jonathan and David understood.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jonathan gave his weapons to the boy. He told the boy, “Take them back into town.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the boy had left, David came out from the south side of the rock and quickly bowed down three times with his face touching the ground. Then they kissed each other and cried together, but David cried the loudest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Go in peace!” Jonathan told David. “We have both taken an oath in Yahweh’s name, saying, ‘Yahweh will be a witness between me and you and between my descendants and your descendants forever.’”
So David left, and Jonathan went into the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David went to the priest Ahimelech at Nob. Ahimelech was trembling as he went to meet David. “Why are you alone?” he asked David. “Why is no one with you?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “The king ordered me to do something,” David answered the priest Ahimelech, “and he told me, ‘No one must know anything about this mission I’m sending you on and about the orders I’ve given you. I’ve stationed my young men at a certain place.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David added, “Now, what do you have to eat? Give me five loaves of bread or whatever you can find.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I don’t have any ordinary bread,” the chief priest answered David. “But there is holy bread for the young men if they haven’t had sexual intercourse today.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David answered the priest, “Of course women have been kept away from us as usual when we go on a mission. The young men’s bodies are kept holy even on ordinary campaigns. How much more then will their bodies be holy today?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the priest gave him holy bread because he only had the bread of the presence which had been taken from Yahweh’s presence and replaced with warm bread that day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That same day one of Saul’s servants who was obligated to stay in Yahweh’s presence was there. His name was Doeg. A foreman for Saul’s shepherds, he was from Edom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David asked Ahimelech, “Don’t you have a spear or a sword here? I didn’t take either my spear or any other weapon because the king’s business was urgent.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The chief priest answered, “The sword of Goliath the Philistine, whom you killed in the Elah Valley, is here. It is wrapped in a cloth behind the priestly ephod. If you want to take it, take it. There’s no other weapon here.”
David said, “There’s none like it. Let me have the sword.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That day David left. He was still fleeing from Saul when he came to King Achish of Gath.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Achish’s officers asked, “Isn’t this David, the king of his country? He’s the one they used to sing about in the dances:
‘Saul has defeated thousands
    but David tens of thousands.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David realized what they had said, he was terrified of King Achish of Gath.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he changed his behavior when he was in their presence and acted insane as long as he was under their authority. He scribbled on the doors of the city gate and let his spit run down his beard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Achish said to his officers, “Look at him! Don’t you see that he’s insane? Why bring him to me?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Do I have such a shortage of lunatics that you bring this man so that he can show me he is insane? Does this man have to come into my house?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David escaped from that place and fled to the cave at Adullam. When his brothers and all the rest of his family heard about it, they went to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then everyone who was in trouble, in debt, or bitter about life joined him, and he became their commander. There were about four hundred men with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From there David went to Mizpah in Moab. He asked the king of Moab, “Please let my father and mother stay with you until I know what Elohim is going to do for me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He brought them to the king of Moab, and they stayed with him as long as David was living in his fortified camp.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Don’t live in your fortified camp,” the prophet Gad told David. “Go to the land of Judah.” So David went to the forest of Hereth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul heard that David and his men had been found. Saul was staying in Gibeah under the tamarisk tree at the worship site with his spear in his hand and all his officials standing around him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said to his officials, “Listen here, men of Benjamin! Will Jesse’s son give every one of you fields and vineyards? Will he make you all officers over a regiment or a battalion of soldiers?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All of you are plotting against me, and no one informed me when my son entered into a loyalty pledge with Jesse’s son. No one felt sorry for me and informed me that my son has encouraged my servant David to ambush me, as he’s doing now.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Doeg from Edom, standing with Saul’s officials, answered him, “I saw Jesse’s son when he came to Ahimelech, Ahitub’s son, in Nob.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahimelech prayed to Yahweh for David and gave him food and the sword of Goliath the Philistine.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king sent for the priest Ahimelech, who was Ahitub’s son, and his entire family who were the priests in Nob. All of them came to the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Saul said, “Listen here, son of Ahitub!”
“Yes, sir?” he responded.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul asked him, “Why did you and Jesse’s son plot against me? You gave him bread and a sword and prayed to Elohim for him so that he can rise up against me and ambush me, as he’s doing now.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahimelech asked the king, “But whom among all your officials can you trust like David? Your Majesty, he’s your son-in-law, the commander of your bodyguard. He’s honored in your own household.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Is this the first time I have prayed to Elohim for him? Not at all! You shouldn’t blame me or anyone in my family for this. I knew nothing at all about this.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul said, “Ahimelech, you and your entire family are going to die.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Turn and kill Yahweh’s priests because they support David,” the king said to the runners standing around him. “When they knew David was fleeing, they didn’t inform me.” But the king’s men refused to attack Yahweh’s priests.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the king said to Doeg, “You turn and attack the priests.” Doeg from Edom turned and attacked the priests, and that day he killed 85 men wearing the linen priestly ephod.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also killed the people of Nob, the city of the priests. Using his sword, he killed men and women, children and infants, cows, donkeys, and sheep.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Ahimelech, Ahitub’s son, had one son who escaped. His name was Abiathar. He fled to David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abiathar told David that Saul had killed Yahweh’s priests.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David told Abiathar, “I knew that day when Doeg from Edom was there that he would be certain to tell Saul. I am the one responsible for all the lives of your family.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Stay with me. Don’t be afraid. The one who is seeking my life is also seeking your life. However, you will be under my protection.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David was asked, “Did you know that the Philistines are fighting against Keilah? They are robbing the threshing floors.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
David asked Yahweh, “Should I go and attack these Philistines?”
“Go,” Yahweh told David, “attack the Philistines, and save Keilah.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David’s men told him, “We’re afraid of staying here in Judah. How much more afraid do you think we’ll be if we go to Keilah against the Philistine army?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David asked Yahweh again, and Yahweh answered him. He said, “Go to Keilah. I’m giving you the power to defeat the Philistines.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David and his men went to Keilah, fought the Philistines, drove off their livestock, and decisively defeated them. So David rescued the people who lived in Keilah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Ahimelech’s son Abiathar fled to David at Keilah, Abiathar brought a priestly ephod with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Saul was told that David went to Keilah, Saul said, “Elohim has delivered him into my hands. He has trapped himself by going into a city which has a gate with a double door held shut by a bar.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Saul called together all the troops to go to war and blockade Keilah, where David and his men were.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David learned that Saul was planning to harm him, he told the priest Abiathar, “Bring the ephod.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David said, “Yahweh Elohim of Israel, I have actually heard that Saul is going to come to Keilah and destroy the city on account of me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Will the citizens of Keilah hand me over to him? Will Saul come here as I have heard? Yahweh Elohim of Israel, please tell me.”
“He will come,” Yahweh answered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Will the citizens of Keilah hand me and my men over to Saul?” David asked.
“They will hand you over,” Yahweh answered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David and his men, about six hundred in all, left Keilah. They went wherever they could go. Then Saul was told, “David has escaped from Keilah!” So he gave up the campaign.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David lived in fortified camps in the desert, and he lived in fortified camps in the mountains of the desert of Ziph. Saul was always searching for him, but Elohim didn’t let him capture David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David was afraid because Saul had come to kill him at Horesh in the desert of Ziph.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul’s son Jonathan came to David at Horesh. He strengthened David’s faith in Yahweh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Don’t be afraid,” he told David, “my father Saul won’t find you. You will rule Israel, and I will be your second-in-command. Even my father Saul knows this.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Both of them made a pledge in Yahweh’s presence. David stayed in Horesh, and Jonathan went home.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the men of Ziph went to Saul in Gibeah. They said, “David is hiding with us in fortified camps at Horesh on the hills of Hachilah, south of Jeshimon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Come, Your Majesty, whenever you want. We will hand him over to you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul responded, “Yahweh bless you for feeling sorry for me!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Please make more plans, and watch where he goes. Who has seen him there? I’m told he’s very clever.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Watch and learn about all the hiding places where he may be hiding, and come back to me with the facts. Then I’ll go with you, and if he’s in the country, I’ll search for him among all the families of Judah.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They left for Ziph ahead of Saul.
David and his men were in the desert of Maon, in the plains south of Jeshimon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Saul and his men came to look for him, David was told the news. So he went to his mountain stronghold in the desert of Maon. Saul heard about it and pursued David into the desert of Maon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul went on one side of the mountain, and David and his men went on the other side of the mountain. David was hurrying to get away from Saul, and Saul and his men were going around the mountain toward David and his men, trying to capture them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then a messenger came to Saul and said, “Come quickly! The Philistines are raiding the country.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul gave up pursuing David and went to fight the Philistines. So that place was called Slippery Rock.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From there David went to stay in the fortified camps of En Gedi.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Saul came back from fighting the Philistines, he was told “Now David is in the desert near En Gedi.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Saul took 3,000 of the best-trained men from all Israel and went to search for David and his men on the Rocks of the Wild Goats.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He came to some sheep pens along the road where there was a cave. Saul went into it to relieve himself while David and his men were sitting further back in the cave.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
David’s men told him, “Today is the day Yahweh referred to when he said, ‘I’m going to hand your enemy over to you. You will do to him whatever you think is right.’”
David quietly got up and cut off the border of Saul’s robe.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But afterward, David’s conscience bothered him because he had cut off the border of Saul’s robe.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said to his men, “It would be unthinkable for me to raise my hand against His Majesty, Yahweh’s anointed king, since he is Yahweh’s anointed.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So David stopped his men by saying this to them and didn’t let them attack Saul.
Saul left the cave and went out onto the road.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Later, David got up, left the cave, and called to Saul, “Your Majesty!” When Saul looked back, David knelt down with his face touching the ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David asked Saul, “Why do you listen to rumors that I am trying to harm you?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Today you saw how Yahweh handed you over to me in the cave. Although I was told to kill you, I spared you, saying, ‘I will not raise my hand against Your Majesty because you are Yahweh’s anointed.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: My master, look at this! The border of your robe is in my hand! Since I cut off the border of your robe and didn’t kill you, you should know and be able to see I mean no harm or rebellion. I haven’t sinned against you, but you are trying to ambush me in order to take my life.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: May Yahweh decide between you and me. May Yahweh take revenge on you for what you did to me. However, I will not lay a hand on you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It’s like people used to say long ago, ‘Wickedness comes from wicked people.’ But I will not lay a hand on you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Against whom has the king of Israel come out? Whom are you pursuing? A dead dog? One flea?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Yahweh must be the judge. He will decide between you and me. He will watch and take my side in this matter and set me free from you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David finished saying this, Saul asked, “Is that you speaking, my servant David?” and Saul cried loudly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He told David, “You are more righteous than I. You treated me well while I treated you badly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Today you have proved how good you’ve been to me. When Yahweh handed me over to you, you didn’t kill me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When a person finds an enemy, does he send him away unharmed? Yahweh will repay you completely for what you did for me today.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now I know that you certainly will rule as king, and under your guidance the kingdom of Israel will prosper.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Swear an oath to Yahweh for me that you will not wipe out my descendants or destroy my name in my father’s family.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David swore to Saul. Then Saul went home, and David and his men went to their fortified camp.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Samuel died, and all Israel gathered to mourn for him. They buried him at his home in Ramah. Then David went to the desert of Paran.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, there was a man in Maon whose business was in Carmel. He was a very rich man. He had 3,000 sheep and 1,000 goats. And he was shearing his sheep in Carmel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This man’s name was Nabal, and his wife’s name was Abigail. She was sensible and beautiful, but he was harsh and mean. He was a descendant of Caleb.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While David was in the desert, he heard that Nabal was shearing his sheep.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David sent ten young men and told them, “Go to Carmel, visit Nabal, and greet him for me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Say to him, ‘May you live long! May you, your home, and all you have prosper!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I hear that your sheepshearers are with you. Your shepherds have been with us, and we have not mistreated them. Nothing of theirs has been missing as long as they’ve been in Carmel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ask your young men, and let them tell you. Be kind to my young men, since we have come on a special occasion. Please give us and your son David anything you can spare.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David’s young men came to Nabal, they repeated all of this to him for David, and then they waited.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Who is David?” Nabal answered David’s servants. “Who is Jesse’s son? So many servants nowadays are leaving their masters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Should I take my bread, my water, and my meat that I butchered for my shearers and give them to men coming from who knows where?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David’s young men returned and told him all this.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Each of you put on your swords!” David told his men. And everyone, including David, put on his sword. About four hundred men went with David, while two hundred men stayed with the supplies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One of the young men told Abigail, Nabal’s wife, “David sent messengers from the desert to greet our master, who yelled at them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Those men were very good to us. They didn’t mistreat us, and we found that nothing was missing wherever we went with them when we were in the fields.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They were a wall protecting us day and night as long as we were watching the sheep near them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, consider what you should do because our master and his whole household are doomed. And he’s such a worthless man that it’s useless to talk to him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Abigail quickly took 200 loaves of bread, 2 full wineskins, 5 butchered sheep, a bushel of roasted grain, 100 bunches of raisins, and 200 fig cakes and loaded them on donkeys.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Go on ahead,” she told her young men, “and I’ll follow you.” But she didn’t tell her husband Nabal about it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She was riding on her donkey down a hidden mountain path when she met David and his men coming toward her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David had thought, “I guarded this man’s stuff in the desert for nothing! Not one of his possessions was missing. Yet, he has paid me back with evil when I was good to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: May Elohim punish me if I leave even one of his men alive in the morning.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Abigail saw David, she quickly got down from her donkey. She immediately bowed down in front of David with her face touching the ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After she bowed at his feet, she said, “Sir, let me be held responsible for this wrong. Please let me speak with you. Please listen to my words.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shouldn’t take this worthless person Nabal seriously. He is like his name. His name is Nabal [Godless Fool], and he’s foolish. But I didn’t see the young men you sent.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Yahweh has kept you from spilling innocent blood and from getting a victory by your own efforts. Now, sir, I solemnly swear, as Yahweh and you live, may your enemies and those who are trying to harm you end up like Nabal.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Here is a gift I am bringing to you. May it be given to the young men who are in your service.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Please forgive my offense. Yahweh will certainly give you, sir, a lasting dynasty, because you are fighting Yahweh’s battles. May evil never be found in you as long as you live.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Even though someone pursued you and sought your life, your life is wrapped in the bundle of life which comes from Yahweh your Elohim. But he will dispose of the lives of your enemies like stones thrown from a sling.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Yahweh does all the good he promised and makes you ruler of Israel,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: you shouldn’t have a troubled conscience because you spilled blood for no good reason and claimed your own victory. When Yahweh has given you success, remember me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David said to Abigail, “Blessed be Yahweh Elohim of Israel, who sent you today to meet me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: May your good judgment be blessed. Also, may you be blessed for keeping me from slaughtering people today and from getting a victory by my own efforts.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But I solemnly swear—as Yahweh Elohim of Israel, who has kept me from harming you, lives—if you hadn’t come to meet me quickly, Nabal certainly wouldn’t have had one of his men left at dawn.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David accepted what she brought him and told her, “Go home in peace. I’ve listened to what you’ve said and granted your request.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Abigail came to Nabal, he was holding a banquet in his home. It was like a king’s banquet. He was in a good mood and very drunk, so she didn’t tell him anything until dawn.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But in the morning, when the effects of the wine had worn off, his wife told him what had happened. Nabal’s heart failed, and he could not move.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: About ten days later Yahweh made him even more sick, and Nabal died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When David heard Nabal was dead, he said, “Blessed be Yahweh, who defended me against the insults of Nabal and kept me from doing wrong. Yahweh has turned Nabal’s own wickedness back on him.”
Then David sent men on his behalf to propose marriage to Abigail.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David’s servants came to Abigail at Carmel, they told her, “David has sent us to you so that we can take you to him to be his wife.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She bowed down with her face touching the ground. “I am ready to serve,” she said. “I am ready to wash the feet of my master’s servants.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Abigail quickly got up and rode on a donkey with five of her female servants following her. So she went with David’s messengers and became his wife.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David also married Ahinoam of Jezreel. Both she and Abigail were his wives.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul had given his daughter Michal, David’s wife, to Palti, Laish’s son, who was from Gallim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people of Ziph came to Saul at Gibeah. “David is hiding at the hill of Hachilah near Jeshimon,” they said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul went to the desert of Ziph, taking with him 3,000 of Israel’s best-trained men to search for David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul camped by the road at the hill of Hachilah near Jeshimon, but David stayed in the desert. When he realized Saul had come to the desert for him,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David sent spies to confirm that Saul had arrived.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David went to the place where Saul had camped. David saw the place where Saul and Ner’s son Abner, the commander of the army, were lying. Saul was lying in the camp, and the troops were camped around him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
David asked Ahimelech the Hittite and Abishai, who was Zeruiah’s son and Joab’s brother, “Who will go with me to Saul in the camp?”
Abishai answered, “I’ll go with you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David and Abishai went among Saul’s troops that night. Saul was lying asleep inside the camp with his spear stuck in the ground near his head. Abner and the soldiers were lying around him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abishai said to David, “Today Elohim has turned your enemy over to you. Please let me nail him to the ground with one stab of the spear. I won’t have to do it twice!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Don’t kill him!” David told Abishai. “No one has ever attacked Yahweh’s anointed king and remained free of guilt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I solemnly swear, as Yahweh lives,” David added, “Yahweh will strike him. Either his time will come when he’ll die naturally, or he’ll go into battle and be swept away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It would be unthinkable for me to attack Yahweh’s anointed king. But please take that spear near his head and that jar of water, and let’s go.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David took the spear and the jar of water near Saul’s head, and they left. All of them were asleep. No one saw them, knew about it, or woke up. Yahweh had made them fall into a deep sleep.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David went over to the other side and stood on top of the hill some distance away. (There was a wide space between them.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then David called to the troops and to Ner’s son Abner. “Won’t you answer, Abner?” he asked.
“Who is calling the king?” Abner asked.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David asked Abner, “Aren’t you a man? Is there anyone like you in Israel? Then why didn’t you guard your master, the king? Someone came to kill His Royal Majesty.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: What you’ve done isn’t good. I solemnly swear, as Yahweh lives, you are dead men. You didn’t guard your master, Yahweh’s anointed king. Look at the king’s spear and the jar of water that were near his head.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Saul recognized David’s voice. “Is that your voice, my servant David?” he asked.
“It is my voice, Your Royal Majesty,” David answered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Why are you pursuing me?” he added. “What have I done? What crime have I committed?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Your Majesty, please listen to my words. If Yahweh has turned you against me, let him be satisfied with an offering. But if mere mortals have turned you against me, let them be cursed by Yahweh. They have prevented me from having a share of Yahweh’s inheritance. ‘Go and serve other gods,’ they tell me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Don’t let my blood fall to the ground, away from Yahweh’s presence. The king of Israel has come to search for one flea like someone hunting a partridge in the hills.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “My servant David,” Saul said, “I have sinned. Come back. I will not harm you again, because you valued my life today. I’ve acted like a fool and made a terrible mistake.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David responded, “Here’s the king’s spear. One of the young men should come over and get it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yahweh will reward any person who is righteous and faithful. Yahweh handed you over to me today, but I refused to attack Yahweh’s anointed king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As I placed great value on your life today, may Yahweh place great value on my life and rescue me from all trouble.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then Saul said, “Blessed are you, my servant David. You will accomplish many things and certainly will succeed.”
So David went his way, while Saul returned home.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David said to himself, “One of these days Saul will sweep me away. The best thing for me to do is to make sure that I escape to Philistine territory. Then Saul will give up looking all over Israel for me, and I’ll escape from him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David went with his 600 men to King Achish of Gath, Moach’s son.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David and his men stayed with Achish in Gath. Each one had his family, and David had his two wives, Ahinoam from Jezreel and Abigail (who had been Nabal’s wife) from Carmel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Saul was told that David had fled to Gath, he didn’t search for him anymore.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David said to Achish, “If you will permit me, let me have a place in one of the outlying towns so that I can live there. Why should I live in the royal city with you?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Achish immediately gave him Ziklag. (This is why Ziklag still belongs to the kings of Judah today.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David stayed in Philistine territory for one year and four months.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David and his men went to raid the Geshurites, the Girzites, and the Amalekites. (They lived in the territory which extends from Telaim to Shur and Egypt.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whenever David attacked the territory, he left no man or woman alive. He also took sheep, cattle, donkeys, camels, and clothing and returned to Achish.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Achish would ask, “Whom did you raid today?”
And David would answer, “the Negev in Judah,” or “the portion of the Negev where the descendants of Jerahmeel live,” or “the portion of the Negev where the Kenites live.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He did not bring a single man or woman back to Gath alive. He thought, “They could tell Achish what I really did.” This was his practice as long as he lived in Philistine territory.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Achish believed David. Achish thought, “He has definitely made his own people in Israel despise him. He’ll be my servant from now on.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At that time the Philistines had gathered their army to fight against Israel. Then Achish said to David, “You need to know that you and your men will be going with me into battle.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Very well,” David responded to Achish, “you will then know what I can do.”
“Very well,” Achish told David, “I will make you my bodyguard for life.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Meanwhile, Samuel had died, and all Israel had mourned for him and buried him in his hometown Ramah. (Saul had rid the land of mediums and psychics.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Philistines assembled and camped in Shunem. Saul also assembled the whole Israelite army, and they camped at Gilboa.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Saul looked at the Philistine army, he was very afraid—terrified.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He prayed to Yahweh, but Yahweh didn’t answer him through dreams, the Urim, or prophets.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Saul told his officers, “Find me a woman who conjures up the dead. Then I’ll go to her and ask for her services.”
His officers told him, “There is a woman at Endor who conjures up the dead.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After disguising himself by putting on other clothes, Saul left with two men and came to the woman that night. He said to her, “Please consult with a dead person for me. Conjure up the person I request.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The woman told him, “You know that Saul rid the land of mediums and psychics. Why are you trying to trap me and have me killed?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Saul took an oath in Yahweh’s name, “I solemnly swear, as Yahweh lives, you will not be harmed if you do this.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Whom should I conjure up for you?” the woman asked.
“Conjure up Samuel for me,” he answered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the woman saw Samuel, she cried out loudly and asked, “Why did you deceive me? You’re Saul!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Don’t be afraid,” the king said to her. “What do you see?”
“I see a god rising from the ground,” the woman answered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“In what form?” he asked her.
She answered, “An old man is coming up, and he’s wearing a robe.” Then Saul knew it was Samuel. Saul knelt down with his face touching the ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Samuel asked Saul, “Why did you disturb me by conjuring me up?”
Saul answered, “I’m in serious trouble. The Philistines are at war with me, and Elohim has turned against me and doesn’t answer me anymore—either by the prophets or in dreams. So I’ve called on you to tell me what to do.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Samuel said, “Why are you asking me when Yahweh has turned against you and become your enemy?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yahweh has done to you exactly what he spoke through me: Yahweh has torn the kingship out of your hands and given it to your fellow Israelite David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yahweh is doing this to you today because you didn’t listen to him or unleash his burning anger on Amalek.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For the same reasons Yahweh will hand you and Israel over to the Philistines. Tomorrow you and your sons will be with me. And then Yahweh will hand Israel’s army over to the Philistines.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Immediately, Saul fell flat on the ground. He was frightened by Samuel’s words. He also had no strength left, because he hadn’t eaten anything all day or all night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The woman came over to Saul and saw that he was terrified. “I listened to you,” she told him, “and I took my life in my hands when I did what you told me to do.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now please listen to me. I will serve you something to eat. Eat it so that you will have strength when you leave.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But he refused. “I don’t want to eat,” he said. Nevertheless, his officers and the woman kept urging him until he listened to them. So he got up from the ground and sat on the bed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The woman immediately butchered a fattened calf that she owned. She took flour, kneaded it, and baked some unleavened bread.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then she served it to Saul and his officers. They ate and left that same night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Philistines assembled their whole army at Aphek, and Israel camped at the spring in Jezreel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Philistine leaders were marching by with their companies and regiments. David and his men were marching in the rear with Achish.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Philistine officers asked, “What are these Hebrews doing here?”
Achish asked the Philistine officers, “Isn’t this David, the servant of King Saul of Israel, who has been with me now for a year or two? I’ve found nothing wrong with him from the day he defected until now.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the Philistine officers were angry with Achish. “Send the man back,” the Philistine officers told him. “Return him to the place you assigned him. He shouldn’t go with us into battle. He shouldn’t be allowed to become our enemy during the battle. Is this man going to try to regain his master’s favor? He’ll do it with the lives of our men!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Isn’t this David of whom people sing in dances:
‘Saul has defeated thousands
    but David tens of thousands’?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Achish called David and told him, “I solemnly swear, as Yahweh lives, you are a dependable man. I consider your campaigning with me a good thing, because I’ve never found anything wrong with you from the day you came to me until now. But the rulers don’t approve of you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So leave peacefully without doing anything to displease the Philistine rulers.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “What have I done?” David asked Achish. “What have you learned about me from the time I came to you until now? Why shouldn’t I fight your enemies, Your Majesty?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Achish answered David, “I admit that in my judgment you’re as good as Elohim’s Messenger. However, the Philistine officers said, ‘He shouldn’t go into battle with us.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Get up early in the morning with Saul’s servants who came with you, and go to the place I have assigned to you. Don’t worry about the unkind words, because I still approve of you. Get up in the morning, and leave when it’s light.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Early the next morning David and his men returned to Philistine territory, while the Philistines went to Jezreel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Two days later, when David and his men came to Ziklag, the Amalekites had raided the Negev, including Ziklag. They had attacked Ziklag and burned it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Although they captured the young and old women who were there, they killed no one. Instead, they had taken the women and other prisoners and gone away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: By the time David and his men came to the town, it had been burned down, and their wives, sons, and daughters had been taken captive.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David and his men cried loudly until they didn’t have the strength to cry anymore.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Amalekites also captured David’s two wives, Ahinoam from Jezreel and Abigail (who had been Nabal’s wife) from Carmel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David was in great distress because the people in their bitterness said he should be stoned. (They were thinking of their sons and daughters. But David found strength in Yahweh his Elohim.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David told the priest Abiathar, Ahimelech’s son, “Please bring me the priestly ephod.” So Abiathar brought David the ephod.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then David asked Yahweh, “Should I pursue these troops? Will I catch up with them?”
“Pursue them,” Yahweh told him. “You will certainly catch up with them and rescue the captives.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David and his 600 men went to the Besor Valley, where some were left behind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David and 400 men went in pursuit, while 200 men who were too exhausted to cross the Besor Valley stayed behind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David’s men found an Egyptian in the open country and took him to David. They gave him food to eat and water to drink.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They gave him a slice of fig cake and two bunches of raisins. After he had eaten, he revived. (He hadn’t eaten any food or drunk any water for three whole days.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
David asked him, “To whom do you belong? Where do you come from?”
“I’m an Egyptian, the slave of an Amalekite,” the young man answered. “My master left me behind because I got sick three days ago.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We raided the portion of the Negev where the Cherethites live, the territory of Judah, the portion of the Negev where Caleb settled, and we burned down Ziklag.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Will you lead me to these troops?” David asked him.
He answered, “Take an oath in front of Elohim that you won’t kill me or hand me over to my master, and I’ll lead you to these troops.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Egyptian led him to them. They were spread out all over the land, eating, and drinking. They were celebrating because they had taken so much loot from Philistine territory and from the land of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From dawn until evening the next day, David attacked them. No one escaped except 400 young men who rode away on camels.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David rescued everything the Amalekites had taken, including his two wives.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nothing was missing—young or old, sons or daughters, the loot or anything else they had taken with them. David brought back everything.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He took all the sheep and the cattle. His men drove the animals ahead of him and said, “This is David’s loot.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David came to the 200 men who had been too exhausted to go with him and had stayed in the Besor Valley. They came to meet David and the people with him. As David approached the men, he greeted them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then every wicked and worthless man who had gone with David said, “Since they didn’t go with us, they shouldn’t be given any of the loot we recovered. Each of them should take only his wife and children and leave.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But David said, “My brothers, don’t do that with the things which Yahweh has given us. He has protected us and handed the troops that attacked us over to us.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Besides, who is going to pay attention to what you have to say in this matter? Certainly, the share of those who go into battle must be like the share of those who stay with the supplies. They will all share alike.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From that time on he made this a rule and a custom in Israel as it is to this day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David came to Ziklag, he sent part of the loot to his friends, the leaders of Judah. He said, “Here is a gift for you from the loot taken from Yahweh’s enemies.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There were shares for those in Bethel, Ramoth in the Negev, Jattir,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Aroer, Siphmoth, Eshtemoa,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Racal, the cities belonging to the Jerahmeelites, the cities belonging to the Kenites,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hormah, Borashan, Athach,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hebron, and to all the places David and his men visited from time to time.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Philistines were fighting against Israel, the men of Israel fled from the Philistines and were killed in battle on Mount Gilboa.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Philistines caught up to Saul and his sons. They killed Jonathan, Abinadab, and Malchishua, Saul’s sons.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The heaviest fighting was against Saul. When the archers got him in their range, he was badly wounded by them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul told his armorbearer, “Draw your sword! Stab me, or these godless men will come, stab me, and make fun of me.” But his armorbearer refused because he was terrified. So Saul took the sword and fell on it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the armorbearer saw that Saul was dead, he also fell on his sword and died with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Saul, his three sons, his armorbearer, and all his men died together that day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the people of Israel on the other side of the valley and across the Jordan River saw that the men of Israel had fled and that Saul and his sons were dead, they abandoned their cities. So the Philistines came to live in these cities.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The next day, when the Philistines came to strip the dead, they found Saul and his three sons lying on Mount Gilboa.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They cut off his head and stripped off his armor. Then they sent men throughout Philistine territory to tell the people this good news in their idols’ temples.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They put his armor in the temple of their goddesses—the Asherahs—and fastened his corpse to the wall of Beth Shan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the people living in Jabesh Gilead heard what the Philistines had done to Saul,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: all the fighting men marched all night and took the dead bodies of Saul and his sons from the wall of Beth Shan. They came back to Jabesh and burned the bodies there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They took the bones and buried them under the tamarisk tree in Jabesh. Then they fasted seven days.
verses.speaker: Narrator
